newsitem.title: UK: Wet Brent trades at May -94 cts, Nigerians weaker.
newsitem.headline: Wet Brent trades at May -94 cts, Nigerians weaker.

text.p: North Sea physical crude differentials again reflected the pressure of persistent oversupply on Tuesday when a Brent Blend cargo traded at a 94 cent discount to May paper, traders said.
That was two cents dearer than the 96 cent differential achieved for the same cargo on Monday, but was a full six cents weaker than values seen on Thursday.
With BP alone holding 10 cargoes of unsold April Brent, values could continue close to a dollar discount for much of the week, some traders said.
BP took their tally of unsold Brents into double figures on Tuesday by keeping a cargo loading April 16-18 brought forward from Wednesday's chains.
An Ekofisk changed hands at unchanged values, with a cargo loading April 22-24 at Dated Brent minus three cents.
Paper also showed weakness. April/May was around -60/-52 cents, with May/June at -18/14 cents and June July at -4/-1 cents.
CFDs were 25 to 15 cents weaker for this week and next week. April 1-4 were equivalent to May -85/-65 cents and April 7-11 was May -65/-60 cents.
April 14-18 traded at June -57 cents, equivalent to May - 41 cents.
A fourth Forties cargo was cancelled on Tuesday because of underperformance at one of the fields contributing to Britain's largest crude stream, oil traders said.
Enterprise cancelled the 600,000 barrel cargo scheduled to load on April 25-30 as a result of lower than expected output from the Scott field.
The four cancellations cut the original April Forties programme by four cargoes to 40, excluding crude piped straight to the Grangemouth refinery.
